{{Infobox person | image = | caption = | title = | birth_date = {{birth date|1880|01|09}} | birth_place = [[New York City]], U.S. | death_date = {{death-date and age|February 16, 1966|January 9, 1880}} | death_place = New York City, U.S. | residence = 4 [[66th Street (Manhattan)|East 66th Street]]
[[Glenmere mansion]]
Champ Soleil | education = | alma_mater = [[Harvard University]] | spouse = {{marriage|Marie Elise Whelen|June 14, 1904|1914|reason=div}}
{{marriage|Donna Fernanda Riabouchinsky|October 22, 1919|1924|reason=div}}
{{marriage|Roberta Willard
|September 24, 1925}} | children = 4 | parents = [[Ogden Goelet]]
[[Mary Wilson Goelet]] | relatives = ''See'' [[Goelet family]] }} '''Robert Wilson Goelet''' (January 9, 1880 – February 6, 1966) was an American social leader, banker, and real estate developer who built [[Glenmere mansion]].{{cite web|last1=Foreman|first1=John|title=Big Old Houses: A Better Fate Than Many|url=http://www.newyorksocialdiary.com/the-way-they-live/2012/big-old-houses-a-better-fate-than-many|website=New York Social Diary|accessdate=29 November 2016|date=14 November 2012}} ==Early life== Goelet was born in 1880. He was the son of [[Mary Wilson Goelet]] (1855–1929), a leader of New York and Newport society,{{cite news|title=MRS. OGDEN GOELET DIES OF PNEUMONIA; Duchess of Roxburghe's Mother Long Noted for Her Lavish Entertaining. WAS HOSTESS TO ROYALTY Edward VII, as Prince of Wales, Among Guests--Sister of Mrs. Cornellus Vanderbilt and R.T. Wilson. Her Hospitality. Duchess of Roxburghe Daughter.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1929/02/24/archives/mrs-ogden-goelet-dies-of-pneumonia-duchess-of-roxburghes-mother.html|accessdate=29 November 2016|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=24 February 1929}} and [[Ogden Goelet]] (1846–1897), a prominent heir and landlord in [[New York City]] who was the great-grandson of [[Peter Goelet]], who begat the Goelet wealth by becoming one of the largest landowners in New York, which reportedly was 55 acres "stretching along the East side from [[Union Square, Manhattan|Union Square]] to [[48th Street (Manhattan)|48th Street]]." His only sibling was his older sister, [[Mary Goelet]], who married [[Henry Innes-Ker, 8th Duke of Roxburghe]] in 1903.{{cite news|title=DUCHESS LEFT FORTUNE; Roxburghe Estate Was Founded by Money of American Heiress|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1937/11/21/archives/duchess-left-fortune-roxburghe-estate-was-founded-by-money-of.html|accessdate=13 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=21 November 1937}}{{cite news|last1=Times|first1=Wireless To The New York|title=DOWAGER DUCHESS OF ROXBURGHE DIES; New York Heiress Was a Close Friend of King George V and Queen Mary|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1937/04/27/archives/dowager-duchess-of-roxburghe-dies-new-york-heiress-was-a-close.html|accessdate=13 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=27 April 1937}} Through his sister, he was the maternal uncle of [[George Innes-Ker, 9th Duke of Roxburghe]] (1913–1974).{{cite news|last1=Times|first1=Special To The New York|title=DUKE OF ROXBURGHE MARRIES IN LONDON|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1954/01/06/archives/duke-of-roxburghe-marries-in-london.html|accessdate=13 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=6 January 1954}} Through his mother, he was a nephew of [[Richard Thornton Wilson, Jr.]], [[Marshall Orme Wilson]], Belle Wilson (the wife of British Ambassador [[Michael Henry Herbert|Sir Michael Henry Herbert]]), and [[Grace Vanderbilt|Grace Wilson]] (the wife of [[Cornelius Vanderbilt III]]).{{cite news|title=To Marry an English Lord|accessdate=March 27, 2016|url=https://www.amazon.com/Marry-English-Anglomania-Really-Started/dp/0894809393}} Through his father, he was a nephew of [[Robert Goelet]],{{cite book |last1=Hutto |first1=Richard Jay |title=The Jekyll Island Club Members |date=2005 |publisher=Indigo Custom Publishing |isbn=9780977091225 |pages=61-63 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FNPoVchaehwC&pg=PA63 |accessdate=10 September 2018 |language=en}} and a first cousin of [[Robert Walton Goelet]].{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Robert W. Goelet Dies In Home At 61. Corporation Director, Owner of Large Realty Holdings Here, Succumbs to Heart Attack. He Inherited $60,000,000. Sportsman, a Leader in Social Circles in Newport and New York, Kin of Early Settlers |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1941/05/03/archives/robert-w-goelet-dies-in-home-at-61-corporation-director-owner-of.html |quote=Robert Walton Goelet of New York and Newport, R. I., a member of one of New York's oldest and wealthiest families, died of a heart attack yesterday at his ... |work=[[New York Times]] |date=May 3, 1941 |accessdate=2010-07-26 }} Goelet attended [[Harvard University]], graduating in 1902, at which time he received one million dollars (equivalent to approximately ${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|1000000|1902|r=0}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars){{inflation-fn|US}} from his father's estate. ==Career== [[File:Mrs. Ogden Goelet Mansion (608 Fifth Avenue).jpg|thumb|right|His parents New York mansion, 608 [[Fifth Avenue]].]] He became "a major force in the development of American railroads, hotels, and real estate," and served as a director of the [[Chemical Bank]] in New York,{{refn|group=lower-alpha|The [[Chemical Bank]] was acquired by [[Chase Manhattan Bank]] in 1996 and became [[JPMorgan Chase]].}} the [[New York Trust Company]], the [[City Investing Building|City Investing Company]], the Fifth Avenue Corporation and the Real Estate Mortgage Commission. After his mother's death, acknowledging the change in the neighborhood from residential to commercial, he had the family home, 608 [[Fifth Avenue]] (located on the southwest corner of 49th and Fifth) in New York City,{{cite news |last1=Miller |first1=Tom |title=The Lost 1884 Ogden Goelet Mansion -- No. 608 Fifth Avenue |url=http://daytoninmanhattan.blogspot.com/2012/04/lost-1884-ogden-goelet-mansion-no-608.html |accessdate=9 September 2018 |work=Daytonian in Manhattan |date=16 April 2012}} tore down and commissioned Victor L.S. Hafner to design the Goelet Building, which stands to this day. In 1947, he attempted to donate [[Ochre Court]], his parents' [[châteauesque]] mansion designed by [[Richard Morris Hunt]] in [[Newport, Rhode Island|Newport]] that was the second largest mansion in Newport after [[The Breakers]],{{cite web |url=http://www.salve.edu/virtualtour/ochre-court |title=Ochre Court |work=[[Salve Regina University]] |accessdate=February 16, 2012}} to the [[United Nations]] as their headquarters. They did not accept the donation and instead, Ochre Court was donated to the [[Sisters of Mercy]] for the formation of [[Salve Regina University|Salve Regina College]], the first Catholic women's college in the state of Rhode Island.{{cite web |last1=Bernier |first1=Maria |title=Guide to the Goelet Family Papers |url=http://library.salve.edu/spec-col/goelet_guide.pdf |website=library.salve.edu |publisher=[[Salve Regina University]] |accessdate=9 September 2018 |date=2008}} ===Military service=== During [[World War I]], Goelet was a [[captain (United States)|captain]] in the infantry in France, first with the [[77th Sustainment Brigade|77th Division]] and later with the [[82nd Infantry Division (United States)|82nd Division]]. For his service, he received the Silver Star for "gallantry" at the [[Meuse-Argonne Offensive|Battle of Meuse-Argonne]]. ==Personal life== On June 14, 1904, Goelet was married Marie Elise Whelen (1880–1959){{cite news |title=MRS. HENRY CLEWS OF ART MEMORIAL; Sculptor's Widow, Who Created Foundation to Aid U.S.-French Ties, Dead ' |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1959/04/16/80769496.pdf |accessdate=10 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=April 16, 1959 |language=en}} in Philadelphia with [[Alice Roosevelt Longworth|Alice Roosevelt]] as one of her bridesmaids.{{cite book |title=Home Journal |date=1904 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0t5gvSr0ZIUC&pg=RA12-PA5&lpg=RA12-PA5 |accessdate=9 September 2018 |language=en}}{{cite news |title=ROBERT GOELET WEDS MISS ELSIE WHELEN Picturesque Ceremony in a Philadelphia Suburb. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1904/06/15/120269398.pdf |accessdate=9 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=June 15, 1904}} She was the daughter of Henry Whelan Jr., a prominent banker from Philadelphia, and the sister of Laura Whelan, who was married to [[Craig Biddle]] (brother of [[Anthony Joseph Drexel Biddle Sr.|Anthony Joseph Drexel Biddle]]).{{cite news |title=ROBERT GOELET TO MARRY. Long-Expected Announcement of His Engagement to Mis Elsie Whelen. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1904/03/27/120284908.pdf |accessdate=9 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=March 27, 1904}} Before their divorce in 1914{{cite news |title=DIVORCES ROBERT GOELET. Final Decree Granted to Wife -Custody of Children Divided. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1914/10/06/106125180.pdf |accessdate=9 September 2018 |work=The New York Times |date=October 6, 1914}} (she later remarried to the artist [[Henry Clews Jr.]] and moved to the [[Chateau de la Napoule]] in France{{cite news |title=MRS. ROBERT GOELET WEDS H. CLEWS, JR. Divorcees Are Married in Her Home a Few Hours After Obtaining License. A SURPRISE FOR FRIENDS Bridegroom, Son of Banker, Is an Artist, and Bride Studied Painting in His Newport Studio. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1914/12/20/301762642.pdf |accessdate=9 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=December 20, 1914}}), they were the parents of two sons:{{cite news |title=GOELET DIVORCE UP TO-DAY. Petitions of Mrs. Robert Goelet and Mrs. Amos T. French Similar. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1914/03/03/101917033.pdf |accessdate=9 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=March 3, 1914}} * Ogden Goelet (1907–1969),{{cite news|title=OGDEN GOELET, SON OF FINANCIER HERE; Heir to Real Estate Holdings Dies in His 62d Year|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1969/10/10/78545989.pdf|accessdate=16 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=10 October 1969}} who married five times, the first being to Florence Enid Connfelt (1912–1992) in 1933.{{cite news |title=ENID CONNFELT WED TO OGDEN GOELET; Bishop Stires and Rev. Richard D. Pope Officiate at Church of Advent, Westbury. MARIAN GRAY HONOR MAID Best Man Is Henry Lewis 3d -- Reception Follows at Brookfield Home of Bride's Parents. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1933/09/22/105804882.pdf |accessdate=10 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=September 22, 1933 |language=en}} They divorced in 1938,{{cite news |title=MRS. OGDEN GOELET GETS RENO DECREE; Former Enid Connfelt Wins Divorce on Ground of Desertion in January, 1937 |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1938/02/22/98100716.pdf |accessdate=10 September 2018 |work=The New York Times |date=February 22, 1938 |language=en}} and later that year, he married Maria Virginia Zimbalist (1915–1981), the daughter of singer [[Alma Gluck]] and [[violin]]ist [[Efrem Zimbalist]].{{cite news |title=Maria V. Zimbalist, Daughter of Violinist, Is Married to Ogden Goelet in Home Here |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1938/04/20/96817290.pdf |accessdate=10 September 2018 |work=The New York Times |date=April 20, 1938 |language=en}} They divorced in March 1941,{{cite news |title=OGDEN GOELET DIVORCED; Former Marie Zimbalist Obtains Decree at Reno |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1941/03/21/85261653.pdf |accessdate=10 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=March 21, 1941 |language=en}} and in April 1941, he married Mimi Nicholson Browne,{{cite news |title=MISS MIMI BROWNE Becomes A Bride; Married to Ogden Goelet of This City in the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas {{!}} SISTER ONLY ATTENDANT {{!}} Couple Go South on Wedding Trip--Bridegroom Member of Distinguished Family |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1941/04/24/85484092.pdf |accessdate=10 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=April 24, 1941 |language=en}} whom he also divorced.{{cite news |title=MRS. GOELET WINS SUIT; Court Quashes Counter-Action of Socially Prominent Husband |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1947/11/20/104377134.pdf |accessdate=10 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=November 20, 1947 |language=en}} He later married for the fifth time to Sarah Sherborne Haigh (1908–1989) in 1963,{{cite news |title=Ogden Goelet to Wed Mrs. Sarah S. Haigh |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1963/12/31/81833325.pdf |accessdate=9 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=December 31, 1963 |language=en}} remaining married until his death in 1969.{{cite news |title=Goelet Widow Gets $200,000 |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1969/10/22/81995689.pdf |accessdate=9 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=October 22, 1969 |language=en}} * Peter Goelet (1911–1986) On October 22, 1919, he remarried to Donna Fernanda (née Rocchi), the Princess Riabouchinsky (1885–1982) at the [[American Church in Paris]]. Donna was born in [[Perugia, Italy]] and was the former wife of Prince Nicholas Riabouchinsky,{{cite news |title=CAPT. ROBERT GOELET MARRIES IN PARIS Weds Mrs. Fernanda Riabouohinsky, Daughter of Italian Teacher of Painting. BRIDE IS FAMOUS BEAUTY Son of Mrs. Ogden Goelet, 24 Years His Bride's Senior, Served in France—Was Cited for Bravery. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1919/10/23/118169944.pdf |accessdate=9 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=October 23, 1919}}{{cite news |title=Russian War Buyer Sees Fight to a Finish Nicolas Riabouchinsky of Moscow, Who Brought Valuable Pictures in His Baggage to New York, Expresses Confidence in the Future of His Nation |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1916/01/09/104019565.pdf |accessdate=10 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=January 9, 1916}} a close friend of Goelet.{{cite book |last1=Rielage |first1=Dale C. |title=Russian Supply Efforts in America During the First World War |date=2002 |publisher=McFarland |isbn=9780786413379 |page=51 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0XauRj69-gsC&pg=PA51&lpg=PA51 |accessdate=10 September 2018 |language=en}} The marriage reportedly infuriated his mother, who refused to receive his wife, and she cut him off from his share in her personal fortune, closed her New York home, her Newport home, and went to England to live.{{cite book |last1=Tully |first1=Andrew |title=Era of Elegance |date=1947 |publisher=eNet Press |isbn=9781618867056 |page=61 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ykB0AgAAQBAJ&pg=PA61&lpg=PA61 |accessdate=10 September 2018 |language=en}} They eventually won over his mother four years later after the birth of a son, but the couple divorced in 1924 and she was later known as the Duchess de Villarosa. Donna and Robert were the parents of one son:{{cite news |title=SUES ROBERT GOELET FOR PARIS DIVORCE; Princess Riabouchinsky is Second Wife of Husband Whom Elsie Whelen Divorced. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1924/02/10/104242781.pdf |accessdate=9 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=February 10, 1924 |language=en}} * Robert Wilson Goelet, Jr. (1921–1989), a film producer who first married [[Llewellyn Thompson|Jane Potter Monroe]] in 1942.{{cite news |title=MISS JANE MONROE IS BRIDE IN BOSTON; Married to Robert Goelet Jr. in Lady Chapel of Episcopal Church of the Advent WEARS WHITE LACE GOWN Miss Hope Tuck Serves as Her: Maid of Honor -- Thomas Long !s Best Man |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1942/03/08/85521612.pdf |accessdate=9 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=March 8, 1942 |language=en}} They divorced, and in 1949, he remarried to [[Lynn Merrick]]. After their marriage, his mother disinherited him.{{cite news |last1=Bergan |first1=Ronald |title=Obituary: Lynn Merrick |url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2007/apr/07/guardianobituaries.obituaries1 |accessdate=10 September 2018 |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=6 April 2007 |language=en}} After a "stormy" marriage, they divorced in 1956.{{cite news |title=Robert Goelet Jr., Film Producer, 68 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/05/obituaries/robert-goelet-jr-film-producer-68.html |accessdate=9 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=July 5, 1989 |language=en}} On September 24, 1925, he married for the third time to Roberta Willard (1891–1949),{{cite news |title=MRS. GOELET, WIFE OF BANKER, IS DEAD; Daughter of Goethals' Aide on Panama Canal Deeded Home in Newport to College |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1949/07/15/85646664.pdf |accessdate=10 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=July 15, 1949 |language=en}} the daughter of Col. Joseph Willard of Newport. Roberta had reportedly been voted "the prettiest debutante there in 1916."{{cite news |title=R. GOELET TO WED ROBERTA WILLARD; Her Mother Announces Her Betrothal at a Dinner Party in Newport. DATE OF WEDDING NOT SET |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1925/08/30/104183494.pdf |accessdate=9 September 2018 |work=The New York Times |date=August 30, 1925 |language=en}}{{cite news |title=MISS WILLARD WED TO ROBERT GOELET; Mothers of Both the Bride and the Bridegroom Are Kept Away by Illness. NUPTIAL PLANS CURTAILED Fewer Than Ten at Ceremony, Which Is in the Willard Home at Newport. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1925/09/25/100021281.pdf |accessdate=9 September 2018 |work=The New York Times |date=September 25, 1925 |language=en}} Both of their mothers were ill and could not attend the wedding, with her mother dying a month later,{{cite news |title=Mrs. Joseph H. Willard. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1925/11/29/100032783.pdf |accessdate=9 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=November 29, 1925 |language=en}} and his mother, a few years later in 1929. Together they were the parents of a daughter: * Mary Eleanor Goelet (1927-1994){{cite news|last1=Times|first1=Special To The New York|title=Goelet Infant Is Named Mary.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1927/09/04/archives/goelet-infant-is-named-mary.html|accessdate=16 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=4 September 1927}} who married (and later divorced) [[Cross & Cross|James Eliot Cross]] in 1949.{{cite news |title=MARY E. GOELET WED; She Becomes Bride in Newport of James Eliot Cross |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1949/06/26/96461816.pdf |accessdate=9 September 2018 |work=The New York Times |date=June 26, 1949 |language=en}} She later married Harold C. King.{{cite news|title=James Cross, Gulf Stream Commissioner|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1997-12-18/news/9712171382_1_planning-board-eliot-town|accessdate=16 April 2017|work=[[Sun Sentinel]]|language=en}} [[File:Glenmere.jpg|thumb|The wall pools of [[Glenmere mansion|Glenmere]]'s southern garden, c. 1920]] Following his donation of Ochre Court in 1947, he purchased a home known as Champ Soleil, designed by [[Polhemus & Coffin]] and located at 601 [[Bellevue Avenue]] in Newport.{{refn|group=lower-alpha|Champ Soleil was completed in 1929 by [[Lucy Wharton Drexel|Lucy Drexel Dahlgren]] was later owned by [[Laura Jane Barney]].{{cite book |last1=Kathrens |first1=Michael C. |title=Newport Villas: The Revival Styles, 1885-1935 |date=2009 |publisher=W.W. Norton & Co. |pages=66, 328-332 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sGXqAAAAMAAJ |accessdate=10 September 2018 |language=en}}}} He served on the boards of [[Bailey's Beach]] and the [[Newport Country Club]], both of which were co-founded by his uncle, and which he was one of the largest shareholders. In New York, he was a member of the [[Knickerbocker Club]], the [[Harvard Club of New York|Harvard Club]], Turf Club, the [[Saint Nicholas Society of the City of New York|St. Nicholas Society]], the [[Piping Rock Club]], and the [[Tuxedo Club]]. He also owned a plantation near [[Charleston, South Carolina]], and was the builder of [[Glenmere mansion]], his estate on the [[Hudson River]] built in 1911 and designed by [[Carrère and Hastings]], where he entertained [[Babe Ruth]] and the [[Edward VIII of the United Kingdom|Duke]] and [[Wallis, Duchess of Windsor|Duchess of Windsor]]. Glenmere was a 62-room manor house in the style of an Italian villa set on 1,322 acres. Goelet died at his home, 4 [[66th Street (Manhattan)|East 66th Street]] in New York City, on February 6, 1966.{{cite news|title=ROBERT GOELET, FINANCIER, DEAD; Real-Estate Millionaire, 86, Was a Social Leader|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1966/02/07/79319261.pdf |accessdate=13 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=7 February 1966}} His funeral was held at St. Thomas’s and he was buried at [[Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx|Woodlawn Cemetery]] in the Bronx. He was worth an estimated $50,000,000 (equivalent to approximately ${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|50000000|1966|r=0}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars){{inflation-fn|US}} at the time of his death. A month after his death, the Chemical Bank of New York, as executor of his estate, listed his New York apartment, which was the entire sixth floor of the building at the southeast corner of [[Fifth Avenue]] and [[66th Street (Manhattan)|East 66th Street]], for sale for $240,000 (equivalent to approximately ${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|240000|1966|r=0}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars){{inflation-fn|US}}.{{cite news |title=Baruch Suite Is Offered for $200,000; THE BARUCH CO-OP AMONG 3 FOR SALE |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1966/03/27/356788052.pdf |accessdate=10 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=March 27, 1966 |language=en}} In October 1966, Goelet's collection of 18th century French furniture, porcelain, and other valuable objects from his New York and Newport homes were auctioned off by [[Parke-Bernet]] in New York.{{cite news |title=GOELET ANTIQUES TO BE AUCTIONED; Parke-Bernet Offers French Furniture of 18th Century |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1966/10/09/284452952.pdf |accessdate=10 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=October 9, 1966 |language=en}} ===Descendants=== Through his eldest son Ogden, he was the grandfather of Ogden Goelet Jr. and Enid Goelet (1934–2005), who married Ranald Trask McNeil (1933–2013), a graduate of [[Columbia University School of the Arts|Columbia University School of Painting and Sculpture]] who served with the [[U.S. Air Force]] in Korea, in 1955.{{cite news |title=R, T. M'NEIL WEDS MISS ENlD GOELET {{!}} Couple Married in Chantry of St. Thomas Church--Bride Wears Organza |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1955/06/25/80775198.pdf |accessdate=10 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=June 25, 1955 |language=en}} ==References== ;Notes {{Reflist|group=lower-alpha}} ;Sources {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{fg|170603046}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Goelet, Robert Wilson}} [[Category:1880 births]] [[Category:1966 deaths]] [[Category:Harvard University alumni]] [[Category:Goelet family]]

{{Infobox person |name=Rolf Dobelli |image=Rolf dobelli 2010.jpg |caption=Dobelli's promotional portrait in 2010 |birth_date={{birth date and age|1966|07|15}} |birth_place=[[Luzern]], Switzerland |occupation=Author, businessman |years_active= }} '''Rolf Dobelli''' (born July 15, 1966 in [[Luzern]], Switzerland<ref>http://www.goodreads.com/author/show/695505.Rolf_Dobelli</ref>) is a [[Swiss people|Swiss]] author and businessman. He began his writing career as a novelist in 2002, but he is best known internationally for his bestselling non-fiction ''[[The Art of Thinking Clearly]]'' (2011, English 2013), for which [[The Times]] has called him "the self-help guru the Germans love".<ref>[http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/life/article3791190.ece The Times, June 2013]</ref>
Born in 1966 in [[Lucerne]], Switzerland, he obtained an [[MBA]] in 1991 from the [[University of St. Gallen]] and a [[PhD]] in [[economic philosophy]] in 1995. In 1999, he co-founded [[getAbstract]], a publisher of book summaries and article abstracts.
In 2003, [[Diogenes Verlag]] (Switzerland) published his first [[novel]], ''Fünfunddreissig'' ("Thirty-five"), followed by ''Und was machen Sie beruflich?'' ("And What Do You Do for a Living?") in 2004, ''Himmelreich'' (The Heavens) in 2006, ''Wer bin ich?'' ("Who am I?") and ''Turbulenzen'' ("Turbulence") in 2007 and ''Massimo Marini'' in 2010. The major themes in Dobelli's novels are the meaning of success and the role of [[randomness]] in business and in life.
Dobelli is the author of ''[[The Art of Thinking Clearly]]'' (''Die Kunst des klaren Denkens''), originally published by [[Carl Hanser Verlag]] in 2011, which was an instant success, entering Germany's [[Der Spiegel]] Bestseller list as number 1.<ref>[http://www.buchreport.de/bestseller/hardcover/bestseller/4.htm Der Spiegel Bestseller List, 12 Jan 2012] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080731040023/http://www.buchreport.de/bestseller/hardcover/bestseller/4.htm |date=2008-07-31 }}</ref> It was the bestselling non-fiction book in Germany and Switzerland in 2012.<ref>[[Der Spiegel]] print edition 1/2013 p. 121</ref> It was translated into English in 2013 and hit the top ten bestseller lists in the U.K,<ref>[[The Times]] bestseller list hardback non-fiction, 21 April 2013</ref><ref>The Sunday Times bestseller list 7 July 2013 (rank number 4)</ref> South Korea, India,<ref>[Crossword book retailer's bestseller list June 2013]</ref> Ireland,<ref>[http://www.writing.ie/news/irish-bestsellers-this-week/ Writing.IE Bestseller List, 14 June 2013]</ref> Hong Kong and Singapore.<ref>[[The Straits Times]] bestseller list non-fiction, 28 April 2013</ref> ''The Art of Thinking Clearly'' was attacked by [[Nassim Nicholas Taleb]] and [[Christopher Chabris]] for [[plagiarism]].<ref>Guido Kalberer, [www.tagesanzeiger.ch/kultur/buecher/Nassim-Taleb-attackiert-Rolf-Dobelli/story/11573752 Nassim Taleb attackiert Rolf Dobelli], [[Tages-Anzeiger]], 12 September 2013.</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fooledbyrandomness.com/dobelli.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-09-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160202004155/http://www.fooledbyrandomness.com/dobelli.htm |archivedate=2016-02-02 |df= }}</ref> [[Christopher Chabris]] has published an example in Dobelli's book that is referenced but does not have quotation marks, and four paragraphs in the notes/references section (unprinted in most editions) without the formally required proper credit. Dobelli acknowledged those errors and they will be fixed.<ref>[http://blog.chabris.com/2013/09/similarities-between-rolf-dobellis-book.html] [http://www.dobelli.com/book-corrections]</ref>
Dobelli advises to "avoid news consumption" <ref>[http://dobelli.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/08/Avoid_News_Part1_TEXT.pdf Avoid News - Towards a healthy news diet] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130117104220/http://dobelli.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/08/Avoid_News_Part1_TEXT.pdf |date=2013-01-17 }}</ref> an idea he learnt from Nassim Taleb and attributed to him, but in one later instance failed to properly credit to Taleb.<ref>[[The Guardian|Guardian]] [https://www.theguardian.com/media/2013/apr/12/news-is-bad-rolf-dobelli News is bad for you – and giving up reading it will make you happier] print and online edition of 13 April 2013</ref> He cites "fifteen reasons to avoid news" in a 2013 blog post.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p018f3h3 "All in the Mind" on BBC Radio 30 April 2013, starting at 15:00 min]. [http://www.dobelli.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/03/Avoid_News_Part1_TEXT.pdf Why you should stay away from news - published online]. [[The Huffington Post]] {{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/danny-rubin/news-is-bad-for-you-rebuttal_b_3092183.html |title=Danny Rubin: News Is Bad for You? Here Are 9 Reasons Why That Idea Is Flat Wrong |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date= |accessdate=2013-08-12}}. [https://www.theguardian.com/media/2013/apr/12/news-is-bad-rolf-dobelli News is bad for you – and giving up reading it will make you happier] - Essay in English published by the [[The Guardian|Guardian]]</ref>
Dobelli is a member of [[Edge Foundation, Inc.]], an association of intellectuals,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.edge.org/memberbio/rolf_dobelli |title=Rolf Dobelli |publisher=Edge.org |date= |accessdate=2013-08-12}}</ref> [[PEN International]], [[Royal Society of Arts]] and founder of the "[[zurich.minds]]" foundation.
==Books== === in German === *Fünfunddreissig (Thirty-five), 2003 *Und was machen Sie beruflich? (And What Do You Do for a Living?), 2004 *Himmelreich (The Heavens), 2006 *Wer bin ich? (Who Am I?), 2007 *Turbulenzen (Turbulence), 2007 *Massimo Marini, 2010 *Die Kunst des klaren Denkens (The Art of Thinking Clearly), 2011 *Die Kunst des klugen Handelns (The Art of Acting Clearly), 2012 === in English === *[[The art of thinking clearly]], 2013 *The art of the good life, Sceptre, 2017

[[Kennedy family]] |signature = Sargent Shriver Signature.svg |education = [[Yale University]] {{small|([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]], [[Bachelor of Laws|LLB)]]}} |allegiance = {{flag|United States}} |branch = {{flag|United States Navy}} |serviceyears = 1941–1945 |rank = [[Lieutenant (navy)|Lieutenant]] |battles = [[World War II]] |mawards = [[Purple Heart Medal]]
[[American Campaign Medal]]
[[Asiatic-Pacific Campaign Medal]]
[[World War II Victory Medal]]{{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B03E5D9143AF930A15757C0A9629C8B63 |title=A Muscular Idealism |date=April 23, 2004 |accessdate=December 5, 2008 |work=[[The New York Times]] |first=Bob |last=Herbert}} }} '''Robert Sargent Shriver Jr.''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|s|ɑr|dʒ|ən|t|_|ˈ|ʃ|r|aɪ|v|ər}}; November 9, 1915 – January 18, 2011) was an American diplomat, politician and activist. As the husband of [[Eunice Kennedy Shriver]], he was part of the [[Kennedy family]]. Shriver was the driving force behind the creation of the [[Peace Corps]], and founded the [[Job Corps]], [[Head Start Program|Head Start]], and other programs as the "architect" of the 1960s "[[War on Poverty]]." He was the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]]'s nominee for Vice President in the [[United States presidential election, 1972|1972 presidential election]]. Born in [[Westminster, Maryland]], Shriver pursued a legal career after graduating from [[Yale Law School]]. An opponent of U.S. entry into [[World War II]], he helped establish the [[America First Committee]] but volunteered for the [[United States Navy]] before the Japanese [[attack on Pearl Harbor]]. During the war, he served in the South Pacific, participating in the [[naval Battle of Guadalcanal]]. After being discharged from the navy, he worked as an assistant editor for ''[[Newsweek]]'' and met Eunice Kennedy, marrying her in 1953. He worked on the 1960 presidential campaign of his brother-in-law, [[John F. Kennedy]], and helped establish the Peace Corps after Kennedy's victory. After Kennedy's assassination, Shriver served in the administration of [[Lyndon B. Johnson]] and helped establish several anti-poverty programs as director of the [[Office of Economic Opportunity]] from October 16, 1964 to March 22, 1968.[http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/?pid=26617 Remarks at the Swearing In of Sargent Shriver as Director, Office of Economic Opportunity.] The American Presidency Project. Retrieved 7 May 2015. He also served as the [[United States Ambassador to France]] from 1968 to 1970. In 1972, Democratic vice presidential nominee [[Thomas Eagleton]] resigned from the ticket, and Shriver was chosen as his replacement. The Democratic ticket of [[George McGovern]] and Shriver lost in a [[United States presidential election, 1972|landslide election defeat]] to Republican President [[Richard Nixon]] and Vice President [[Spiro Agnew]]. Shriver briefly sought the [[Democratic Party presidential primaries, 1976|1976 Democratic presidential nomination]] but dropped out of the race after the first set of primaries. After leaving office, he resumed the practice of law, becoming a partner with [[Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson]]. He also served as president of the [[Special Olympics]] and was briefly a part-owner of the [[Baltimore Orioles]]. He was diagnosed with [[Alzheimer's disease]] in 2003 and died in [[Bethesda, Maryland]] in 2011. ==Early life and career== Shriver was born in [[Westminster, Maryland]], the younger son of Robert Sargent Shriver Sr. and his wife Hilda, who had also been born with the surname "Shriver" (they were second cousins).{{cite book|last1=Shorter|first1=Edward|title=The Kennedy Family and the Story of Mental Retardation|date=2000|publisher=Temple University Press|isbn=1-566-39782-0|page=61}} Sarge's elder brother was Thomas Herbert Shriver. Of partial [[German American|German ancestry]], Shriver was a descendant of David Shriver, who signed the [[List of delegates to the Maryland Constitutional Convention (1776)|Maryland Constitution and Bill of Rights at Maryland's Constitutional Convention of 1776]].{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,906202-1,00.html |title=The New Nominee No Longer Half a Kennedy |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date=August 14, 1972 |accessdate=September 27, 2008 }} He spent his high school years at [[Canterbury School (Connecticut)|Canterbury School]] in [[New Milford, Connecticut]], which he attended on a full scholarship. He was on Canterbury's baseball, basketball, and football teams, became the editor of the school's newspaper, and participated in choral and debating clubs.http://www.newstimes.com/local/article/R-Sargent-Shriver-built-roots-at-New-Milford-s-1025181.php After he graduated in 1934, Shriver spent the summer in Germany as part of The [[Experiment in International Living]], returning in the fall of 1934 to enter [[Yale University]]. An early opponent of American involvement in [[World War II]], Shriver was a founding member of the [[America First Committee]], an organization started in 1940 by a group of [[Yale Law School]] students, also including future President [[Gerald Ford]] and future Supreme Court Justice [[Potter Stewart]], which tried to keep the US out of the European war.{{cite book|last1=Kauffman|first1=Bill|last2=Sarles|first2=Ruth|authorlink2=Ruth Sarles|title=A story of America First: the men and women who opposed U.S. intervention in World War II|year=2003|publisher=Praeger|location=New York|isbn=0-275-97512-6|page=xvii}} Nevertheless, Shriver volunteered for the [[US Navy]] before the [[attack on Pearl Harbor]] and said he had a duty to serve his country even if he disagreed with its policies. He spent five years on active duty, mostly in the [[South Pacific Ocean|South Pacific]], serving aboard the {{USS|South Dakota|BB-57}}, reaching the rank of [[lieutenant (naval)|lieutenant]] (O-3). He was awarded a [[Purple Heart]] for wounds he received during the [[Naval Battle of Guadalcanal|bombardment]] of [[Guadalcanal]].{{cite news|last=Schoifet |first=Mark |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-18/sargent-shriver-kennedy-kin-and-founder-of-u-s-peace-corps-dies-at-95.html |title=Sargent Shriver, Kennedy In-Law, Founder of U.S. Peace Corps, Dies at 95 |publisher=Bloomberg |date= January 19, 2011|accessdate=February 22, 2011}} Shriver's relationship with the Kennedys began when he was working as an assistant editor at ''[[Newsweek]]'' after his discharge from the Navy. He met Eunice Kennedy at a party in New York, and shortly afterwards, family patriarch [[Joseph P. Kennedy Sr.]] asked him to look at diary entries written by his eldest son, [[Joseph P. Kennedy Jr.]], who had died in a plane crash while he was on a military mission during World War II. Shriver was later hired to manage the [[Merchandise Mart]], part of Kennedy's business empire, in Chicago, Illinois.{{cite news| url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/01/18/AR2011011805116.html| title = Sargent Shriver dies at 95; founded Peace Corps| author = Patricia Sullivan|author2=Emma Brown | date = January 18, 2011| work = [[The Washington Post]]| accessdate =January 21, 2014}} After a seven-year courtship, Shriver married [[Eunice Kennedy Shriver|Eunice Kennedy]] on May 23, 1953, at [[St. Patrick's Cathedral, New York|St. Patrick's Cathedral]] in New York City. She was the third daughter of Joseph Kennedy Sr. and [[Rose Kennedy]].{{cite web|url=http://www.jfklibrary.org/Historical+Resources/Archives/Archives+and+Manuscripts/Shriver.Sargent/fa_shriver_long.htm |title=R(obert) Sargent Shriver: Papers (#214) - John F. Kennedy Presidential Library & Museum |publisher=Jfklibrary.org |accessdate=February 22, 2011}} They had five children: [[Bobby Shriver|Robert Sargent "Bobby" Shriver III]] (born April 28, 1954), [[Maria Shriver|Maria Owings Shriver]] (born November 6, 1955), [[Timothy Shriver|Timothy Perry Shriver]] (born August 29, 1959), [[Mark Shriver|Mark Kennedy Shriver]] (born February 17, 1964), and [[Anthony Shriver|Anthony Paul Kennedy Shriver]] (born July 20, 1965). The Shrivers were married for 56 years, and often worked together on projects.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xt-i-rjJMjwC&printsec=frontcover&dq=sargent+shriver&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjNx53cgs7dAhViylQKHT56BqgQ6AEILDAA#v=onepage&q=kiss&f=false|title=A Good Man: Rediscovering My Father, Sargent Shriver|last=Shriver|first=Mark|date=2012-06-05|publisher=Henry Holt and Company|isbn=9780805095326|language=en}} Shriver was admitted to practice law in the [[District of Columbia]], [[Illinois]], and New York, and at the US Supreme Court.{{cite web |url=http://www.ffhsj.com/index.cfm?pageID=42&itemID=580 |title=Sargent Shriver |publisher=Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson LLP |accessdate=June 7, 2008}} A devout Catholic, Shriver attended daily [[Mass (liturgy)|Mass]] and always carried a [[rosary]] of well-worn wooden beads.{{cite web|url=http://peacecorpsonline.org/messages/messages/2629/1009097.html |publisher=National Catholic Reporter |title=Sargent Shriver and the politics of life |date=August 30, 2002}} He was critical of abortion and was a signatory to "A New Compact of Care: Caring about Women, Caring for the Unborn", which appeared in the ''[[New York Times]]'' in July 1992 and stated that "To establish justice and to promote the general welfare, America does not need the abortion license. What America needs are policies that responsibly protect and advance the interest of mothers and their children, both before and after birth."{{cite web |url=http://www.catholic.org/politics/story.php?id=40015 |publisher=Catholic Online |title=Pro-Life Liberal Sargent Shriver Dies |date=January 19, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110124045218/http://www.catholic.org/politics/story.php?id=40015 |archivedate=January 24, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} ==Political career== ===1950s=== He was appointed to and served as president of the Chicago Board of Education.{{Cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/obituaries/la-me-sargent-shriver-20110119,0,3549392.story|title=R. Sargent Shriver dies at 95; 'unmatched' public servant and Kennedy in-law|last=Mehren|first=Elizabeth|date=January 18, 2011|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=January 18, 2011}} ===1960s=== [[File:Sargent Shriver-JFK.jpg|thumb|left|Shriver and JFK at the White House in August 1961.]] When brother-in-law [[John F. Kennedy]] ran for president, Shriver worked as a political and organization coordinator in the Wisconsin and West Virginia primaries. During Kennedy's presidential term, Shriver founded and served as the first director of the [[Peace Corps]] from March 22, 1961 to February 28, 1966.{{cite web |url=http://www.peacecorps.gov/index.cfm?shell=learn.whatispc.history.pastdir&btn=1 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20031226082426/http://www.peacecorps.gov/index.cfm?shell=learn.whatispc.history.pastdir&btn=1 |archivedate=December 26, 2003 |title=About the Peace Corps : Past Directors |accessdate=7 May 2015}} After [[Assassination of John F. Kennedy|Kennedy's assassination]], Shriver continued to serve as Director of the Peace Corps and served as Special Assistant to President [[Lyndon B. Johnson|Lyndon Johnson]]. Under Johnson, he created the [[Office of Economic Opportunity]] with William B. Mullins and served as its first Director.{{cite news| url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C0CE2D81630F935A25756C0A966958260 | work=The New York Times | title=W. B. Mullins, 52, A Founding Official Of the Peace Corps | date=May 16, 1990 | accessdate=May 23, 2010}} He is known as the "architect" of the Johnson administration's "[[War on Poverty]]". Hired by President Johnson to be the "salesman" for Johnson's [[War on Poverty]] initiative, Shriver initially was "not interested in hearing about community action proposals." The [[Job Corps]] movement was more consistent with his goals. Thus, soon after his appointment, Shriver "moved quickly to reconsider the proposed antipoverty initiative."Vinovskis, M. A. (2008) Birth of Head Start: Preschool education policies in the Kennedy and Johnson administrations Chicago, IL: University of Chicago Press. p. 42-43 Shriver founded numerous social programs and organizations, including [[Head Start Program|Head Start]],{{cite web|url=http://www.paheadstart.org/UserFiles/File/General_History.pdf|title=Head Start History: 1965-Present|publisher=Pennsylvania Head Start Association|accessdate=January 21, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110515203448/http://www.paheadstart.org/UserFiles/File/General_History.pdf|archivedate=May 15, 2011|df=mdy-all}} [[Volunteers in Service to America|VISTA]], [[Job Corps]], Community Action, [[Upward Bound]], Foster Grandparents, Legal Services, the National Clearinghouse for Legal Services (now the Shriver Center), Indian and Migrant Opportunities and Neighborhood Health Services, in addition to directing the Peace Corps. He was active in [[Special Olympics]], founded by his wife Eunice. Shriver was awarded the [[Pacem in Terris Award|Pacem in Terris Peace and Freedom Award]] in 1967. It was named after a 1963 [[encyclical]] letter by [[Pope John XXIII]] that calls upon all people of good will to secure peace among all nations. ''[[Pacem in terris]]'' is [[Latin]] for 'Peace on Earth'. Shriver served as [[U.S. Ambassador to France]] from 1968 to 1970, becoming a quasi-celebrity among the French for bringing what ''[[Time magazine|Time]]'' magazine called "a rare and welcome panache" to the normally sedate world of international diplomacy.{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,839591,00.html |title=Diplomacy: The Liveliest Ambassador|date=November 1, 1968|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]| accessdate=January 18, 2011}} ===1970s and Vice Presidential/Presidential candidacies=== {{main|United States presidential election, 1972}} During the [[1972 Democratic National Convention]] in [[Miami Beach]], Florida, [[George McGovern]] considered Shriver as a vice presidential candidate, but his campaign was unable to reach Shriver, who was at the time visiting [[Moscow]], [[Soviet Union]].{{cite web | url =http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2011/01/18/sargent-shrivers-america-friends-and-family-remember-a-new-frontier-hero.html | title = Sargent Shriver's America | last = Clymer | first = Adam | date = January 18, 2011 | website = The Daily Beast | publisher = | access-date = March 21, 2016 | quote = "In fact, McGovern said this week, he probably would have chosen instead of the ill-starred Eagleton at the Miami Beach convention, but Shriver was traveling in Russia and could not be reached by phone to be offered the nomination." }} McGovern then selected [[Thomas Eagleton]] instead, who later resigned from the Democratic ticket following revelations of past mental health treatments. Shriver then replaced Eagleton on the ticket. The McGovern-Shriver ticket lost to Republican incumbents [[Richard Nixon]] and [[Spiro Agnew]]. Shriver unsuccessfully sought the Democratic presidential nomination in [[United States presidential election, 1976|1976]]. In the months before [[Democratic Party presidential primaries, 1976|the primaries]] began, political observers thought that Shriver would draw strength from legions of former colleagues from the Peace Corps and the War on Poverty programs, and he was even seen as an inheritor of the Kennedy legacy, but neither theory proved true.{{Cite magazine |last=Koster |first=R. M. |authorlink=R. M. Koster |date=February 1976 |title=The Democratic Super Bowl |magazine=[[Harper's Magazine|Harper's]] |publisher=Harper's Foundation |volume=252 |issue=1509 |pages=14–17 |url=https://harpers.org/archive/1976/02/the-democratic-super-bowl/ |accessdate=November 18, 2018 }}{{subscription}} His candidacy was short-lived and he returned to private life.{{cite web |url=http://www.jfklibrary.org/JFK+Library+and+Museum/News+and+Press/JFK+Presidential+Library+Opens+Sargent+Shriver+Collection.htm |title=JFK Presidential Library Opens Sargent Shriver Collection |publisher=John F. Kennedy Presidential Library & Museum |accessdate=June 7, 2008 |date=February 1, 2005}} ==Life after politics== He was associated with the [[Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson]] law firm in Washington, D.C., where he specialized in international law and foreign affairs, beginning in 1971. He retired as partner in 1986 and was then named [[of counsel]] to the firm.{{citation needed|date=July 2011}} In 1981, Shriver was appointed to the [[Rockefeller University Council]], an organization devoted exclusively to research and graduate education in the biomedical and related sciences. In 1984, he was elected President of [[Special Olympics]] by the Board of Directors; as President, he directed the operation and international development of sports programs around the world. Six years later, in 1990, he was appointed Chairman of the Board of Special Olympics. He was an investor in the [[Baltimore Orioles]] along with his eldest son [[Bobby Shriver]], [[Eli Jacobs]], and [[Larry Lucchino]] from 1989Hyman, Mark S. "Orioles are sold: $70 million; Buyers say team will stay," ''[[The Baltimore Sun]]'', December 7, 1988 to 1993. ==Illness and death== Shriver was diagnosed with [[Alzheimer's disease]] in 2003. In 2004, his daughter, [[Maria Shriver|Maria]], published a children's book, ''What's Happening to Grandpa?'', to help explain Alzheimer's to children. The book gives suggestions on how to help and to show love to an elderly person with the disease.{{cite book |last1=Shriver|first1=Maria|authorlink1=Maria Shriver|title=What's Happening to Grandpa? |isbn=978-0-316-00101-4 |publisher=Little, Brown Young Readers |date=April 28, 2004}} In July 2007, Shriver's son-in-law, California Governor [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]], speaking in favor of [[stem-cell research]], said that Shriver's Alzheimer's disease had advanced to the point that "Today, he does not even recognize his wife."{{cite news |url=https://www.thestar.com/News/article/219810 |title=Terminator gunning to save lives; California governor, McGuinty sign stem-cell research deal in bid to `cure a lot' of illnesses |work=[[Toronto Star]] |accessdate=June 7, 2008 |date=May 31, 2007 |author1=Benzie, Robert |author2=Ferguson, Rob }} Maria Shriver discusses her father's worsening condition in a segment for the four-part 2009 [[HBO]] documentary series ''The Alzheimer's Project'' called ''Grandpa, Do You Know Who I Am?'', including describing a moment when she decided to stop trying to correct his various delusions.HBO Documentary, The Alzheimer's Project, 2009, [http://www.hbo.com/alzheimers/grandpa-do-you-know-who-i-am.html ''Grandpa, Do You Know Who I Am?''] with Maria Shriver. On August 11, 2009, Shriver's wife of 56 years, Eunice, died at the age of 88. He attended her wake and funeral in [[Centerville, Massachusetts|Centerville]] and [[Hyannis, Massachusetts]].{{cite news| url=http://www2.turnto10.com/news/2009/aug/14/biden_among_invitees_to_eunice_kennedy_shriver_fun-ar-53547/|title=Special Olympians, family celebrate Eunice Kennedy Shriver|date=August 13, 2009| publisher=Associated Press via turnto10.com|accessdate=January 20, 2011}} Two weeks later, on August 29, 2009, he also attended the funeral of her brother [[Ted Kennedy]] in Boston, Massachusetts.{{cite web|url=http://www.nwitimes.com/entertainment/columnists/offbeat/article_ace6e7f3-36dc-5e9e-85e8-31b27ad22ada.html|title=OFFBEAT: Sen. Ted Kennedy's funeral unites family with words of inspiration|last=Potempa|first=Philip|date=September 1, 2009|work=Times of Northwest Indiana|accessdate=January 20, 2011}} Shriver died on January 18, 2011, in [[Suburban Hospital]] in [[Bethesda, Maryland]], at age 95.{{cite news| url = https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/19/us/politics/19shriver.html | title = R. Sargent Shriver, Peace Corps Leader, Dies at 95| last = McFadden | first = Robert D.| authorlink = Robert D. McFadden |date = January 18, 2011| work = The New York Times| accessdate =January 18, 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/sargent-shriver-dies-peace-corps-founder-vp-candidate/story?id=12627926|title=Sargent Shriver Dies: Peace Corps Founder, VP Candidate |last=McGuire|first=Bill|date=January 18, 2011|publisher=ABC News|accessdate=January 18, 2011}} Shriver's family released a statement calling him "a man of giant love, energy, enthusiasm, and commitment" who "lived to make the world a more joyful, faithful, and compassionate place." President [[Barack Obama]] also released a statement, calling Shriver "one of the brightest lights of the greatest generation". Aaron S. Williams, the director of the Peace Corps, said in a statement, "The entire Peace Corps community is deeply saddened by the passing of Sargent Shriver." He further noted that Shriver "served as our founder, friend, and guiding light for the past 50 years" and that "his legacy of idealism will live on in the work of current and future Peace Corps volunteers."{{cite web|url=http://www.peacecorps.gov/index.cfm?shell=resources.media.press.view&news_id=1693|title=Peace Corps Mourns the Loss of Founder and Visionary Father, Sargent Shriver|date=January 18, 2011|work=News Releases & Statements|publisher=[[Peace Corps]]|accessdate=January 19, 2011}} He is buried alongside his wife Eunice at St. Francis Xavier Cemetery in Centerville, Massachusetts. ==Legacy== In 1993, Shriver received the [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] [[Four Freedoms Award|Freedom From Want Award]]. On August 8, 1994, Shriver received the [[Presidential Medal of Freedom]], the United States' highest civilian honor, from President [[Bill Clinton]]. In December 1993, the [[University of Maryland, Baltimore County]] created the Shriver Center in honor of Shriver and his wife. The center serves as the university's applied learning, civic engagement, and applied learning organization. The Shriver Center also is home to the Shriver Peaceworker Program and the Shriver Living Learning Community.http://shrivercenter.umbc.edu/history/ The Job Corps dedicated a Center to his name in 1998 - the "Shriver Job Corps Center" - located in [[Devens, Massachusetts]].{{cite web| url=http://learningtogive.org/papers/paper274.html |title=Shriver, Robert Sargent (Informational Paper)|last=Schada|first=Emilie|date=Fall 2005|publisher=Learning to Give|accessdate=January 18, 2011}} The National Clearinghouse for Legal Services (renamed the National Center on Poverty Law in 1995) was renamed the Shriver Center in 2002 and each year awards a Sargent Shriver Award for Equal Justice.{{cite web|url=http://www.povertylaw.org/about-us/sargent-shriver-our-founder|title=Our Founder, Sargent Shriver|publisher=SHRIVER CENTER: Sargent Shriver National Center on Poverty Law|accessdate=January 19, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060516193528/http://www.povertylaw.org/about-us/sargent-shriver-our-founder|archivedate=May 16, 2006|df=mdy-all}} Sargent Shriver Elementary School, located in [[Silver Spring, Maryland]], is named after him.{{cite web|url=http://www.gazette.net/stories/111407/olnenew134117_32355.shtml |title=Hands-on lessons for Shriver students |publisher=Gazette.net |date=November 14, 2007 |accessdate=February 22, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.gazette.net/stories/091306/takonew203021_31953.shtml |title=New school year, new elementary school |publisher=Gazette.net |date=September 13, 2006 |accessdate=February 22, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.montgomeryschoolsmd.org/schools/shriveres/aboutus/biography.aspx |title=Who is Sargent Shriver? |publisher=Montgomeryschoolsmd.org |date=January 24, 2011 |accessdate=February 22, 2011}} In January 2008, a documentary film about Shriver aired on [[PBS]], titled ''American Idealist: The Story of Sargent Shriver''. Following his death, Daniel Larison wrote:
Shriver was an admirable, principled, and conscientious man who respected the dignity and sanctity of human life, and he also happened to be a contemporary and in-law of Kennedy. Not only did Shriver represent a "link" with JFK, but he represented a particular culture of white ethnic Catholic Democratic politics that has been gradually disappearing for the last fifty years. A pro-life Catholic, Shriver had been a founding member of the America First Committee, and more famously he was also on the 1972 antiwar ticket with George McGovern. In short, he represented much of what was good in the Democratic Party of his time.Larison, Daniel [http://www.amconmag.com/larison/2011/01/24/shriver-and-lieberman/ Shriver and Lieberman], ''[[The American Conservative]]''

{{Orphan|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = Seokhyo Jang | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1957|10|27}} | birth_place = [[Seoul]], [[South Korea]] | education = [[Inha University]] (BA)
[[University of Minnesota]] (MBA) | occupation = President & CEO, KOGAS
Chairman, Korea Gas Union | module = {{Infobox Korean name|child=yes | hangul = {{linktext|장|석효}} | hanja = ! | mr = Chang Sŏkhyo | rr = Jang Seokhyo}} }} '''Seokhyo Jang''' (born 27 October 1957) is President & CEO of the [[Korea Gas Corporation]] (KOGAS) and Chairman of the Korea Gas Union (KGU). Jang came through alongside South Korea's entry into the world gas market and became a prominent member of the emerging gas market in Asia. ==Background== Jang graduated from Jungdong High School in Seoul in 1975. He received a BA in business and economics from Inha University in 1982 and joined KOGAS the next year. In 1989, he received an MBA from the [[University of Minnesota Duluth]], with a dissertation on economic policies in South Korea during the post-[[Park Chung-hee]] era.{{cite web|url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/economic-policy-of-korea-during-1979-84/oclc/68959460|title=Economic policy of Korea during 1979-84|publisher=Worldcat.org|accessdate=21 October 2014}} ==Work at KOGAS== Jang has been the President & CEO of KOGAS since 2013.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/finance/stocks/companyOfficers?symbol=036460.KS|title=Korea Gas Corp (036460.KS) People - Reuters.com|publisher=Reuters.com|accessdate=21 October 2014}} KOGAS is the largest LNG buyer in the world and operates four LNG terminals in South Korea. He is the first president to have been appointed from within the company.{{cite web|url=https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/biz/2013/07/123_139936.html|title=Jang becomes first insider to head KOGAS|publisher=Koreatimes.co.kr|accessdate=21 October 2014}} Prior to becoming CEO, Jang worked with global partners in LNG purchasing and has experience in marketing and resource divisions. He is credited with developing a close working relationship with other buyers in Asia to ensure security in energy demand and supply.{{cite web|url=http://www.kogas.or.kr/en/who/ceo/curriculum.action|archive-url=https://archive.is/20141021050419/http://www.kogas.or.kr/en/who/ceo/curriculum.action|dead-url=yes|archive-date=21 October 2014|title=KOGAS - Our History - 2010's|publisher=Kogas.or.kr|accessdate=21 October 2014}} In addition to business endeavors, Jang has been behind KOGAS's increased involvement in CSR programs. In 2014, KOGAS ran a training program in South Korea for teams in Iraq and supported training programs and gas pipeline construction in Mozambique.{{cite web|url=http://www.etoday.co.kr/news/section/newsview.php?idxno=879328|title=[소통과 나눔] 장석효 가스공사 사장 "사회공헌 공익법인 설립이 최종 목표"|work=이투데이|accessdate=21 October 2014}} ==Work at KGU== Since 2013, Jang has also been the Chairman of the Korea Gas Union, representing more than 70 local companies and organizations in the industry. He is currently South Korea's candidate for the presidency of the International Gas Union.{{cite web|url=http://www.wgc2021koreabid.com/sub/Candidature/candidate.php|title=WGC 2021|publisher=Wgc2021koreabid.com|accessdate=21 October 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141021162930/http://www.wgc2021koreabid.com/sub/Candidature/candidate.php|archivedate=21 October 2014|df=}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20140111014343/http://www.kogas.or.kr/en/main.action Korea Gas Corporation] official website {{DEFAULTSORT:Jang, Seokhyo}} [[Category:1956 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Seoul]] [[Category:Inha University alumni]] [[Category:University of Minnesota alumni]] [[Category:South Korean businesspeople]]

{{Advert|date=September 2016}} {{Chinese name|[[Chen (surname)|Tan]]}} {{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Tan Suee Chieh | image = | image_size = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1959|05|07}} | birth_place = [[Malaysia]] | residence = [[Singapore]] | education = | alma_mater = [[London School of Economics]], [[Columbia University]] | occupation = Retired | years_active = 2013 - 2016 | box_width = }}
'''Tan Suee Chieh''' ({{zh|s=陈诸杰|zh|t=陳諸傑|p=Chén Zhū Jié}}) was appointed the Group Chief Executive at NTUC Enterprise on 1 October 2013. He is the father of two children, a boy and an elder girl, at the ages of 9 and 12 respectively.<ref>http://www.income.com.sg/AboutUs/Releases/2013/May09.asp</ref>
NTUC Enterprise, set up in July 2012, is the holding co-operative of the existing group of NTUC co-operatives including NTUC Fairprice, NTUC Income, NTUC First Campus, NTUC FoodFare, NTUC Unity Healthcare, NTUC Eldercare and NTUC Learning Hub. As at 2012, the organisations collectively employ 14, 000 staff, serve 2 million customers and record a combined annual revenue of $8 billion. NTUC Enterprise is the single largest shareholder of each of the NTUC social enterprises.
NTUC Enterprise’s main objective is to enable the NTUC social enterprises to achieve significant scale in order to meet the needs of Singaporeans for affordable and quality products and services. These include insurance, investments and retirement planning; child care and early education; training for workers and professionals; healthcare and pharmacies; long term care for the elderly; supermarkets; and the provision of food at food courts, hawker centres, coffee shops and through catering.<ref>http://www.income.com.sg/AboutUs/Releases/2013/May09.asp</ref>
Previously Tan Suee Chieh was Chief Executive of NTUC Income Insurance Co-operative Limited in [[Singapore]] from February 2007 to September 2013. He has served as a member of the organisation’s Board of Directors since 2003.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.income.com.sg/aboutus/annreport/2009.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-05-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110915151041/http://www.income.com.sg/aboutus/annreport/2009.pdf |archivedate=2011-09-15 |df= }}</ref> Prior to that, he held the position of President, Asia Pacific Region of the SHL Group plc, a British human resource consultancy firm and a world leader in objective assessment and psychometric instruments. From 1981 to 2001, he was with the [[Prudential plc]] and held several senior positions including the Company Actuary of Prudential Malaysia, Chief Executive of Prudential Singapore and Managing Director, Established Markets of Prudential Asia.
Tan Suee Chieh’s directorships include International Cooperative and Mutual Insurance Federation and Allnations Board. Tan Suee Chieh is also the Co-chairman of the Institute of Service Excellence@SMU, Vice Chairman of the Singapore Children’s Society Executive Committee, a member of the Board of Governors of the Asia Pacific Risk and Insurance Association, Advisory Board Member of the Centre for Strategic Leadership at National University of Singapore and Sim Kee Boon Institute for Financial Economics at Singapore Management University, and Trustee of the Singapore London School of Economics (LSE) Trust.<ref>http://www.ntuclearninghub.com/board-of-directors;jsessionid=C87989D75C14CB3A0803BA55A4E729E0</ref>
He is a Fellow of the Royal Statistical Society and Institute of Actuaries, and was a Past President of the Life Insurance Association of Singapore<ref>http://www.lia.org.sg/about/committee</ref> as well as the Actuarial Society of Malaysia. Tan Suee Chieh has a first class honours degree from the [[London School of Economics]], and a master's degree in Social Organizational Psychology from [[Columbia University]], New York.
In 2013, Tan Suee Chieh was the recipient of Singapore Business Award’s<ref>http://www.sbawards.com.sg</ref> Outstanding CEO of the Year,<ref>http://www.sbawards.com.sg/awards_winners_2012.html</ref> the Ruth Wong Award from the Singapore Children's Society,<ref>http://www.childrensociety.org.sg/index.php?option=com_k2&view=item&layout=item&id=46&Itemid=47</ref> the Friend of Labour Award from Singapore’s National Trades Union Congress,<ref>http://www.ntuc.org.sg/wps/portal/up2/home/aboutntuc/newsroom/mediareleases/mediareleasesdetails?WCM_GLOBAL_CONTEXT=/content_library/ntuc/home/about+ntuc/newsroom/media+releases/5c6fb5004f6d868f90cbf4bda6c1e78c {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140106161305/http://www.ntuc.org.sg/wps/portal/up2/home/aboutntuc/newsroom/mediareleases/mediareleasesdetails?WCM_GLOBAL_CONTEXT=%2Fcontent_library%2Fntuc%2Fhome%2Fabout+ntuc%2Fnewsroom%2Fmedia+releases%2F5c6fb5004f6d868f90cbf4bda6c1e78c |date=2014-01-06 }}</ref> and the Lifetime Achievement Award conferred by the Institute of Advertising Singapore <ref>http://www.ias.org.sg/</ref> in 2012.<ref>http://www.advertisinghalloffameawards.com/</ref> Tan Suee Chieh was also named in the Prestige Singapore List 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://prestige-singapore.com.sg/node/593 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-05-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130508023828/http://prestige-singapore.com.sg/node/593 |archivedate=2013-05-08 |df= }}</ref>
